title: Using Postgres with Node
content:
When creating a node project, a database will often need to be used in order to store data such as user information.  This post will guide us through a simple set up to get started with node using postgres.

For those who don't know [Postgres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PostgreSQL) is a free and open source RDBMS.  I have been working with it for a bit now, and have found it similar to SQL Server in a lot of ways.  I find the syntax of Postgres to be quite natural.  

## Starting off

[Download and install Postgres](https://www.postgresql.org/download/) Postgres.  It should work for all operating systems.

## Initialize the Database

We can use the `psql` command with `-d` to select the database and `-U` to select the user.

`psql -d postgres -U postgres`

## Create a role

Once logged in, create a role called `me` with a password of your choosing.

`CREATE ROLE base_user WITH LOGIN PASSWORD 'your password';`

To view all of the roles in the database, run `\du`.


Now you can exit by typing `exit;`. 


## Create a database

Log back into the database with the base_user. 

`psql -d postgres -U base_user`

Now that we are in, it is time to create a database.

`CREATE DATABASE your_database`

You can use the `\list` command to see all of the databases

Use `\c your_database` to connect to the database.


## Create a table

Once connected to the DB, we can create a table to hold some blog posts:


```
CREATE TABLE posts (
    id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
    title VARCHAR(100),
    text text,
    image VARCHAR(100),
    date_posted timestamp
);
```

Now that we have created a blog posts table, let us insert a post:

```
INSERT INTO posts (title, text, image, date_posted)
VALUES('First Post', 'My first post', '/image.png', CURRENT_TIMESTAMP);
```

Now to see it in the database:

`SELECT * FROM posts;`
